Keep it cold. Keep it classy.By Adam RapoportApril 2, 2019FacebookTwitterEmailPhoto by Alex LauFacebookTwitterEmailThis is Highly Recommend, a column dedicated to our very opinionated editors' favorite things to eat, drink, and buy.I’ll never mix a cocktail as deftly as they do at New York’s Le Coucou or a L.A.’s Majordomo. But I can cop their barware, particularly the Nick and Nora glass. At just five ounces, it’s far more sensible than one of those oversize martini troughs you get at the club—because, really, when you’re drinking a cocktail served up, you don’t want it edging into that lukewarm territory when you’re only halfway finished. Keep it small, keep it cold. You learn that in 10th-grade physics class, right? Oh, and perhaps most important is the glass’s provenance. It’s named for the boozy, quick-talking couple in Dashiel Hamett’s 1934 novel The Thin Man. They’re the couple we all want to be, always dressed for a night out, always with a quip at the ready, and always—always—with a drink in hand. Their namesake glass appropriately honors their art deco–era swag. With its swank gold trim and curved silhouette, it makes you feel all classy—even if you don’t know how to mix a Manhattan.Buy It: Nick and Nora glasses, $42 for six at food52.comAll products featured on Bonappetit.com are independently selected by our editors.
